Also, for anyone that thinks DEI means that if two candidates are completely equal, you have to choose the minority, I’m sorry but you don’t understand how hiring and candidate selection works. People are not economic units. There’s no perfect way to evaluate them and there is NEVER a situation where two candidates are completely equal in skill level, education, experience, interview ability, personality, etc. It just doesn’t happen. There may be times when you’ve got two good candidates that might be tough to choose between, but that doesn’t mean you go with the minority. In those cases, HR generally works with the hiring manager to decide which qualifications would be the most important. Maybe for a sales role, you have to great candidates but one is better at phone sales and one seems to be better at door to door sales so you choose based on which is most prevalent in the company.

Things like blind resume review are moreso meant to prevent implicit bias. You may not consciously choose to favor white people over black people when screening candidates, but multiple studies have shown that resumes with “black sounding names” are less likely to be called than resumes with “white sounding names”. So blind resume screening helps to mitigate that bias.

Some companies have been able to secure lower interest rates on loans by tying their borrowing terms to achieving diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) targets. This arrangement, often part of Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) initiatives, allows organizations to receive financial incentives for meeting specific DEI benchmarks. For example, a company may benefit from reduced interest rates if it increases the percentage of minority employees or female executives by a predetermined amount. Conversely, failing to meet these goals can lead to higher borrowing costs.

An example of a DEI practice: Blind hiring, also sometimes called blind recruiting or blind resume screening, is the process of removing identifying information from candidates’ resumes or applications to reduce hiring bias. Key information like the candidate’s name or any demographic data that may lead to bias on the part of the hiring team is obscured or removed when applications are reviewed under blind hiring. Then, the hiring team can review the resume/CV or application with a focus on the applicant’s skills and work experience.
